data.title: Simple Triads
data.statement:
(Note: this problem is simplified, meaning that we won't be worrying about enharmonic equivalents. There will be inaccuracies in the statement because of this, but bear with it)

In western music, we assign 12 distinct labels to notes according to their pitch:
`...C C# D D# E F F# G G# A A# B...`
This order is cyclical, meaning that the note above B is C, and the note below C is B. The difference in pitch between any two adjacent notes is called a semitone.

Each note can be the root of a triad. A triad is a chord consisting of three notes, each separated by either 3 or 4 semitones. Depending on this separation, the triad can be considered one of four main types:
`major: 4 + 3 (ex: C E G)
minor: 3 + 4 (ex: C D# G)
diminished: 3 + 3 (ex: C D# F#)
augmented: 4 + 4 (ex: C E G#)`
All four of these example triads have a root note of C. But a triad can have any note as its root, by simply transposing the notes while maintaining the same intervals between them.

Given a root note and a triad type, output the three notes in the triad.
data.constraints:
[[R]] is one of "C", "C#", "D", "D#", "E", "F", "F#", "G", "G#", "A", "A#", or "B".
[[T]] is either "major", "minor", "diminished", or "augmented".
